abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Karachi Water Supply
            Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The project achieved
            most of its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been substantial, sustainability is likely,
            and both the Bank and Borrower acted satisfactorily. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, projects to
            increase bulk water supply to major urban centers can
            increase the supplier's revenue generating capacity and
            improve service levels to consumers by including secondary
            distribution network components. Second, provision of a
            continuous supply of water at workable pressures must
            precede any phased program of domestic metering. Third,
            institutional development is possible, even in unpromising
            conditions, with sustained technical assistance and training
            inputs over an extended period. Fourth, further dialogue
            between the Association and the Borrower is necessary to
            minimize delays in approvals from the government. Lastly,
            achieving full financial viability may have to be approached
            gradually at first when working with a new agency and
            consolidating formerly dispersed functions for the first
            time in a large and rapidly growing city.
